There is an amazing country that uses digital health in the right way! In the keynote I gave about Privacy in the Digital Health Era at the recent GLOBSEC event, I analyzed patients' freedom of choice from the digital health perspective. 1) In China, the freedom of choice patients have about digital health technologies is limited because the government makes them use A.I. and other ways of obtaining data about them. 2) In Rwanda, the freedom of choice is there but limited as otherwise they don't get access to healthcare, only through digital health technologies. 3) In the US, patients have a lot of freedom of choice but without proper incentives, medical professionals are not encouraged to get involved. Which country's example do you think I used as the best in the world? Please cast your vote by leaving a comment. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #speaker   #keynote   #speakerlife

Though American women were "officially" granted the right vote through ratification of the 19th Amendment in August 1920, it took a quite a while longer for Black American women to fully enjoy that freedom. Some say we're still battling, thanks to voter suppression and other tactics aimed at silencing people of color. But this year, Black America must pay tribute to people like the late Emma Sanders, who squared off against some of the most vicious racists America ever produced in Mississippi to ensure that her own party did not discriminate against Black people. I know the path in my journey is paved by the sacrifices of men and women like Sanders. I'm determined her efforts won't be in vain this November.

How many of us will have the  #courage  and acumen to cannibalise 100% of our revenue-generating products and focus on emerging opportunities in the hope of taking our company to new heights? Intel Corporation  had a  #crisis  when the markets started moving towards cheaper and better memory chips. Andrew Grove, a legend to the engineers in the 80s, made massive successful  #pivots           - Taking Intel out of their dominant market, memory chips         - Entering the new emerging market for microprocessors         - Creating defensible competitive advantage that has lasted to this day While this year has been difficult for the society at large and for many of us in the start-up ecosystem, it has been especially difficult for founders. Others before us have faced  #crisis , albeit in different ways. Whether it was the financial crisis or the dot-com crash or an internal crisis specific to a company, there are so many examples of transformational companies and inspirational leaders that transcended a crisis. We can certainly learn from their journeys. These episodes of the  #KalaariPodcast  come from our continued commitment to empower and encourage entrepreneurs.  podcasts@kalaari.com https://lnkd.in/eAA6Wry

TOP Medical Gadgets of 2021? Check out some of my picks from this year's virtual  CES 2021  event based on the collection of our friends over at  Medgadget ! The most obviously good idea: VitalSight by  OMRON Group , a system that connects an Omron blood pressure monitor and weight scale to a clinical EMR via a special wireless hub. The one that sounds too good to be true: Quantum Operation is like a smartwatch that is claimed to be able to continuously monitor glucose without needles. The one that should be on the market already: Valencell announced a calibration-free, cuffless blood pressure technology that can be used in wearables on the finger, wrist, and ear. The weirdest idea: Somno, the Sleep Robot, that contains sensors to measure your breathing and helps generate its own ‚Äúbreathing pattern‚Äù that your body will mimic to help fall asleep faster. #CES   #wearables   #healthgadgets   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology

I published this infographic last week and recevied excellent feedback from you. Many thanks for that!  A bit of a context: it's not surprising that by September in 2019, there are already more medical studies mentioning machine or deep learning than in 2018.  It was also expected that oncology, pathology and radiology stand out when it comes to using A.I. methods in medicine. However, I was surprised to see so many studies in psychiatry, surgery and neurology while you don't see discussions, news and announcements about those developments often. At the same time, it seems that cardiology, ophthalmology and dermatology, the specialties with the most exciting news and developments seem to be underrepresented. The explanation could lie in the method I used to mine the database but it's still interesting. (Right click on the image and choose open in new tab for high resolution.) #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

When you‚Äôre  #perceptive , you‚Äôre good at understanding and figuring things out. Perceptive people are insightful, intelligent, and able to see what others cannot. They envision the possibilities, embracing what could be, rather than being satisfied with the status quo of what is.   They use the  #softskills  of  #listening  to make them sensitive and responsive to their team‚Äôs needs;  #awareness  of others to fuel their ability to truly ‚Äúsee‚Äù people beyond the fa√ßade of their armored shells and then ask probing questions to understand better what matters most to them; and  #empathy  because they know the power of understanding their audience is paramount to business success.   These leaders realize that it‚Äôs not about them, and know that to  #communicate  and  #connect , they must put other people‚Äôs needs first.   Positive leaders tend to have a growth  #mindset  or one in which they believe they can‚Äîand will‚Äîimprove, and see every opportunity as a chance to grow and learn.   They‚Äôre  #curious  and tolerant of new ideas and people and are less like to be thrown off course because of an unexpected setback. They empower others to make decisions. And their openness builds  #trust  naturally, which allows them to connect with others more easily.   #leadership   #positivity   #emotionalintelligence

‚ÄúJust checking in.‚Äù ‚ö†Ô∏è WARNING! ‚ö†Ô∏è  Using ‚Äújust‚Äù doesn‚Äôt make you sound less aggressive; it weakens your message, dilutes its impact, and signals that you and your request aren‚Äôt very important. Here‚Äôs how to drop it: First, become more mindful of your wordsüß† Scan your  #emails , texts, and messages (and better yet, read them out loud). You might be shocked to learn how often that seemingly innocuous word pops up in  #communication .  Next, determine what you wantüéØ Identify if you‚Äôre looking for a status update or trying to stay on someone‚Äôs radar‚Äîas well as the urgency‚Äî so you can craft an appropriate message. Finally, substitute new, action-oriented phrasesüöÄ Instead of ‚Äújust checking in,‚Äù which screams ‚Äúthis isn‚Äôt important or timely‚Äù to your intended audience, try an equally polite but far more direct approach: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd love to hear how the (EVENT/PROJECT) is going/went. Could you give me a quick status update by end-of-day?‚Äù Or ‚ÄúYikes! If your inbox is anything like mine, messages tend to get buried. I wanted to make sure things were still in progress. Let me know if you need any help.‚Äù By removing ‚Äújust‚Äù from your  #business   #writing , you‚Äôll add more power to your words and, more importantly, improve your chances of a speedy response. #leadership   #career   #IlluminateMe 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

How do you even begin to persuade someone who sees the world completely differently than you do? You must provide evidence they're likely to respect. Remember that people differ in background, upbringing, and culture; what one person finds convincing may not work for another. That‚Äôs why you must closely examine the arguments of your conversation partner. Ask yourself: ‚Ä¢	Who influences and inspires them?  ‚Ä¢	What research or sources do they cite?  Next, you can seek data and expert opinions from sources they are likely to heed. (Be careful not to misquote or take information out of context, which will erode your credibility.) These efforts are time-consuming and challenging. But it‚Äôs a well-spent investment, because it allows you to present evidence in a way that‚Äôs more appealing to your partner instead of wasting time on arguments they‚Äôre never likely to consider. Read more about how to achieve emotionally intelligent influence in Ch 6 of my new book, "EQ Applied: The Real-World Guide to Emotional Intelligence":  https://amzn.to/2sxFLho   #EmotionalIntelligence   #BestAdvice   #leadership   #empathy   #PersonalDevelopment   #management   #negotiation   #relationships   #influence   #respect   #EQ   #EQApplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

3D bioprinting has recently seen some setbacks, especially due to Organovo's announcement about changing the company's course.  But this is something to provide hope again. A novel type of ink enables bioengineers to print bone-like material at room temperature with living cells. It's a big feat considering the fact that bone is a mixture of living and inorganic compounds in a highly structured mineral matrix. The team is trying to print larger samples and has begun small animal tests to see if a print can repair a large wound. In the US, the FDA has already signaled that 3D-printed bone technologies are eligible for FDA clearance. I‚Äôve explored what 3D bioprinting can do today and what it promises for tomorrow in various parts of my e-books on The Medical Futurist. Steve Jobs is best known for conducting one of the most stunning business turnarounds in history: leading Apple from the brink of bankruptcy to become the most valuable company in the world.  But many who worked with the famous founder had a love/hate relationship with their boss. Yes, he was inspiring and innovative. But he could also be overbearing, impatient, arrogant. In fact, it was those latter traits that led to Jobs infamously leaving Apple back in 1985, as Jobs and Apple's board simply couldn't see eye to eye. In the eyes of many, Jobs was a "brilliant jerk." So why is it, you may ask, that in a world that seems to increasingly value collaboration and soft skills like emotional intelligence, do brilliant jerks continue to succeed? The answer's not as simple as you think. (Read more in today's column.) #apple   #emotionalintelligence   #SteveJobs   #management   #leadership   #brilliantjerks   #eqapplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

Have you ever wondered how generalists thrive in a specialized world? I recently had a chance to sit down with  David Epstein , author of Range, a fantastic book that covers this topic. Personally, I found the concepts of kind and wicked learning environments to be an interesting part of the book. David‚Äôs message: ‚ÄúIn wicked learning environments, breadth is the hack.‚Äù Watch the clip below and leave us a comment about how you‚Äôve found that having a breadth of experience or specialization has helped in your career or facilitated your learning! #Specialization   #CrossFunctionality   #Generalist   #Range   #Indistractable P.S. David‚Äôs book, Range, and my new book, Indistractable, were recently placed on the BookPal Longlist for the 2019 Outstanding Works of Literature (OWL) Award in the ‚ÄúBig Idea‚Äù category. The five books in each of the fifteen categories represent the top reading recommendations for individuals and teams to inspire new ideas, expand perspectives, and fall in love with reading. Congrats to all other authors and works on the Longlist! Check out the full release at the link in the comments below.

Dogs are people‚Äôs best friends‚Ä¶Especially Now.
 
 Studies show that they help us lower our blood pressure and deal with stress. But we don‚Äôt need studies to tell us what we know already! Dogs also help us get more exercise and spend more time in nature. They always love us and they are always happy to see us. In some ways, dogs show us what ‚Äògoodness‚Äô looks like in all of us too!
 
 Due to the ongoing pandemic, there has been an onslaught of negative news that can cause us to get mired in the spiral of depressing articles. However, it seems that a spike in dog adoptions during COVID-19 is one positive outcome that we can feel good about, as adoptions increased significantly in March and April. 
 
 So if you have a dog, or cat, or are thinking of adopting, make sure you have the  time--and love in your heart‚Äîto commit to them‚Ä¶Like they will commit to you.
 
 FTI Consulting‚Äôs Lindi Jarvis, CA, CFA, CPA CFF, and Vincent Flores, CFE contributed to this story.

Do you think about what you consume? I am not talking about food. I am talking about all your intellectual and digital consumption habits‚Ä¶the books you read, the shows you watch, the instagram accounts you follow. Here‚Äôs why -  Your output is only ever going to be as good as your input. I am downright snobbish about how I spend my time and what I consume. I don't mindlessly scroll through social media feeds. (I don‚Äôt even have Facebook downloaded on my phone - shhh). Your mental input will determine the quality of your life. And THAT is how you stay on track with your goals, aspirations, and hopes for life. What‚Äôs something you consume daily that you could trade for a better substitute? P.S. - Pre-COVID, I loved exploring new cities after my keynote. Great way to get fresh input. This was taken in London. I get so many bad pitches on here (via in-mail) it's incredible. People offering me services that are entirely irrelevant to my job, do I look like I want cheaper toner or to outsource cold calling? Linkedin should offer receivers a chance to "vote down" bad inmails, and give this feedback to senders.    People write one standard pitch and send it to thousands of people because the incremental cost of each receiver is zero.  But there should be a cost, instant blocking is one option when I have time. I guess being less miserable, I should post my free course on how to best pitch here. https://skl.sh/tomgoodwin

I‚Äôve learned a few things about  #content :   Just because you write something doesn‚Äôt make it valuable to someone else; it‚Äôs up to the reader to decide.   If you only use your content to sell, you‚Äôll turn people off. Instead, strive to be of service.   If you go on and on, meandering your way through a very long post with little punctuation, run-on sentences, and no clear point, you‚Äôll lose people.   If a reader takes the time to like, comment, and share your stuff, make sure to acknowledge their kindness.   And on that note, be sure to like, comment and share other people‚Äôs content that you think your network would find valuable. If it resonated with you, it probably will with others.   The best way to discover interesting and valuable content is to read ‚Äî a lot.   Follow people whose writing you admire, whether in your industry or not, and seek many sources of information, even if it makes you uncomfortable. You never know what you‚Äôll learn and from whom. Be open.   Content can inform, entertain, persuade, or inspire. Choose wisely.   Be yourself. Write the way you speak.   And be consistent ‚Äî in your creation, your voice, your sharing, your engagement.   Because my biggest takeaway is this:  Content may be king, but content comes from people. And people connect with people.

"What would you tell entrepreneurs that see your success and think you are too perfect to experience challenges?"üôÑ Oh jeez. I had a fantastic call with best selling author of "Why Me First" and Mindset/Performance Coach,  Kajal Khurana  from Singapore. I had to contain my laughter on-air because I've been dealing with rejection a bit more than usual. Three opportunities fell apart over the past two weeks. A rejection from a local publication for the second time. Personal health issues. And more... But at this moment when I was supposed to mentor others, I was able to recenter and digest my own advice. ‚¨á Lean into the rejection and understand that there is more out there for you. Your future holds greater things and losing these opportunities makes room for even BIGGER ones! Sometimes rejection is proof that you are going OUT there and doing MORE üëâ and that's a sign of effort on its own! Be proud of how far you've come, even if it isn't where you thought you should be. Agree? üëá #Rejection

In the formative stages of a startup, hiring the right talent is among the most important things a founder will have to do. And it‚Äôll be worth considering tapping into the skills and expertise of senior professionals while they are at it.¬† I am reminded of the book ‚ÄòOutliers‚Äô by Malcolm Gladwell where he notes that 10,000 hours is the magic number for greatness. That you need to have practiced and to have apprenticed for at least 10,000 hours before you get good at a task. In fact, senior professionals and retirees come having incubated their skills and talent for much longer than that. And, therefore, they are worth more for their experience than what their age accredits them with. Whether you engage them full-time or part-time, as a consultant or as a part of the in-house team, it‚Äôs certainly a good idea for young founders enroll the expertise of someone who‚Äôs navigated the deep waters of a formal organization and can guide them in their journey to building one. Perhaps I am so much in favor of this because I am aging myself! Nevertheless, with average lifespan expected to improve in the years to come - 120 years as per some estimates - we have to start thinking about longer-term productivity measures and workforce inclusion.

I don't know when ageist, misogynistic name bullying became a thing and acceptable, but it would be really awesome it that would stop. Someone's mother, daughter, sister, relative, friend is named Karen. Or Susan. Or Jenny. Or Sally. As someone who has personally been name bullied for years, I can tell you that it's not "cool" or "socially acceptable". It's ignorant, and hurtful. If you're using the Karen meme/reference (or Susan, or any other name), I kindly ask you to stop. If you see others doing that, please take the time to educate them that it's not OK to make people feel ashamed of their name, and kindly ask them to stop.  #kindness   #humanity   #dobetter

For a  #FlashbackFriday  during  #WorldBreastfeedingWeek2019 , I'm thinking back to the June 2018 graduation ceremony for  #midwives  at the  #EdnaAdanUniversity  in  #Hargeisa ,  #Somaliland . That's when I met some of the most enthusiastic, energetic and inspiring women I will EVER meet. Many had overcome incredible odds to have the privilege of being mentored by  Edna Adan Ismail . One of the young midwives I met, Kaltoun Yasin, sent me a  Facebook  instant message today to let me know that she is participating in  Harvard University 's  summer  #globalhealth  program, and that she led a presentation on  #maternalmortality  and  #morbidity  yesterday. Kaltoun took great pride in telling the audience that Madame Edna has surpassed her original goal of training 1,000 midwives in Somaliland, and that maternal deaths have dropped significantly since the training program began. At a time when I almost dread engaging with  #socialmedia  each day, I was so grateful that Kaltoun reached out to share her fantastic news. I'm determined to counteract the toxin and negativity in this world with good news like this just as often as I can. Midwife International   Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health #midwifery   #reproductivehealth   #reproductivejustice   #midwivessavelives   #Africa   #maternalhealth

We are in the midst of the holiday season! As we approach the new year, I want to reflect on all that has happened in the past twelve months. I had a chance to travel the world, visiting beautiful countries like The United Kingdom, Australia, Thailand, and others! I released my second book, Indistractable, to an outpouring of support from all over the world. I had the opportunity to serve and impact many people through my work, resulting in recognition as a LinkedIn Top Voice in Tech for 2019 and nominations for other accolades. Above all else, I began to take back control of my attention, my time, and my life, leading to countless memories made with my family, friends, and loved ones. Through it all, I have emerged endlessly grateful for all that I am able to do and enjoy on a daily basis. I will continue to approach my work and my relationships with the same optimism that I have in the past. 2019 has been great! I have a feeling that 2020 will be even better. To you, my digital community, I say thank you for an incredible year. Happy Holidays and Happy New Year! I‚Äôll see you in 2020! üëã #Indistractable   #HappyHolidays   #Gratitude   #Reflection

More  Netflix  history. Prior to 2004/2005, the grey "security screen" printed on the inside of the DVD mailer that prevented people from being able to see what movie was being sent, was a tangle of grey squiggly lines.  After chatting with our Ops team, it was revealed that it didn't need to be that, it's just what was done. So, we changed it to genres instead.   Very few, if anyone, ever took the time to look inside at it. But it was an easy, low-cost way for us to express the Netflix brand. #netflix   #brand   #branding   #dvdmailer   #securityscreen

Consider enrolling in this course on Trauma Anniversaries at Rutgers Graduate School of Social Work, Dec. 9 online from 9 --12. See link to learn about course and registration. $60.  https://lnkd.in/dpyNStH .     In addition to social workers, this will be a valuable course for school psychologists, educators, HR personnel, among others. The point is that many anniversaries are coming up and the prior traditions for dealing with anniversaries have changed. How do we handle the pandemic anniversary and the anniversaries of those who passed away from COVID? How do we deal with anniversaries of traumatic events like suicides and shootings and death by overdoses?  We need to plan and reflect ahead of time so we don't end up retriggering older trauma.  Hope to see you there. The time to do the planning is now.

Our sales team called themselves "data slingers."  10 years ago I was hired by  Mark J. Feldman  to grow a data services brand in a then-emerging  #B2B   #martech  space.  There were only ~100 tools on the map as  #demandgen  teams bought our prospect lists to fuel email/call blitzes.  Some did it well, others simply spammed the living daylights out of those CSV files. Today, not much has changed, and yet, everything is different. Over a decade later, even with 10x more tools, the task of acquiring contacts still threatens to derail even the best laid plans - but this time, it's  #ABM  at risk.  Why can't teams find the right contacts for accounts? Why don't more demand gen pros think in an account-based way, like Sales? Are we ever going to shake our MQL-based ethos? Mark is now the head of revenue operations at Localytics, and I've asked him back for a reunion with me live this Friday at 1:00pm ET for a conversation about how things have changed in 10 years, and today, how to solve this new (but old) ABM data problem.  Live here on LinkedIn we'll dig into: - The messy yet critical task of choosing target accounts, and why less is more - How to find, and use, contact records appropriately  - The truth about working with data slingers like us See you there?

I want to be honest with you. üëáüèΩ I quit my full time job when I was 22 to start my first company. I had no plan. And I guess long term that worked out for me.  But where I wish I could go back and reframe my thinking is this: I thought it was wrong to build something on the side.  I thought I would lose respect if I took a part-time job (even though I was struggling to keep the lights on). I looked down on people that didn‚Äôt jump all in. Which was SO naive of me.  I thought building a business was easy. Because the people I followed kind of made it look easy. One of the things I struggle with most as a creator & entrepreneur is showing the reality. I don‚Äôt show: ‚úÖ The boring stuff. ‚úÖ Us getting ripped apart by our business coach every week üòÖüò≠. ‚úÖ How much work actually goes into this. ‚úÖ The many mistakes we make.  ‚úÖ And I could go on and on. Thank you  Cory Savage  for prompting this thought. And thank you i.c stars for asking me to do the commencement speech this year.  2020 I want to spend more time talking about (and showing) the stuff that many of us tend to avoid. On Saturday, Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos posted a letter to Amazon employees on Instagram, detailing part of his company's strategy for the coming months in response to the novel coronavirus. One line that stuck out to me more than all the rest: "My own time and thinking is now wholly focused on COVID-19 and on how Amazon can best play its role." Take a moment to let that sink in: Time and again, Bezos has emphasized that Amazon's strategy is a long-term one, more concerned with continuing to evolve and diversify than with short-term goals and profit, something that investors have not always understood or appreciated.  But now, Bezos has made clear that he's entirely focused on adapting his business to a disease that no one even knew about a few months ago. So, what are the lessons for you & your business? The time for wishful thinking is over. The sooner you figure out a way to adapt to the effects of the coronavirus, the better the chance your business has to survive. (Read more in today's column.) #leadership   #management   #Amazon   #Microsoft   #coronavirus   #COVID19   #innovation   #EmotionalIntelligence #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

Years ago I was in my first role as a manager, and I experienced an exchange I‚Äôll never forget.  I chastised a team member‚Äîwe‚Äôll call him David‚Äîfor a major blunder. My point was valid, but I surely could have delivered it better. David‚Äôs response was quick and cutting:  ‚ÄúYou know, you‚Äôre the kind of manager the rest of us hate.‚Äù Ouch. Of course, David could have been more tactful. But there was no use dwelling on that; there was value in this perspective.  So, I took a few moments to let my emotions settle, then came back to David. I asked him why he felt the way he did, and learned from his honesty. In the end, it made me a better manager‚Äîand it showed David that I wasn‚Äôt the jerk that he thought I was. That's the value of honest feedback, even if it hurts to hear: It will help you grow... If you let it. In Other News: A Win For Patients Personal Digital Charts as I call them, or soon to be known as ‚Äòpersonal digital medical records‚Äô are coming to your smart phone soon! Federal officials on Monday released groundbreaking rules that will let patients download their electronic health records and other health care data onto their smartphones. ‚ÄúPatients should have control of their records, period. Now that‚Äôs becoming a reality,‚Äù said Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar. ‚ÄúThese rules are the start of a new chapter in how patients experience American health care.‚Äù Who are the winners? Patients, people and medical providers who want to understand, manage and control their medical and healthcare needs. Who are the losers? Electronic Medical/Health Record (EMR/EHR) companies who want to own your data to make even more money off your pain and suffering. Finally patients will have all the information at their fingertips  to help them make timely decisions ‚Äîa good first step for all of us.

What is keeping you sane? What's keeping me sane, while I wait for a deus ex machina to flip the switch that will return everything to normal, is my trusty rusty exercise bike, purchased years ago for $200 from a neighbourhood gym that was upgrading its equipment. On the surface, the Cybertruck launch was a disaster. Even many Tesla fans admitted they thought the new E-Truck was ugly. And after Musk boasted that the truck's windows were practically unbreakable, Tesla lead designer Franz von Holzhausen, um...broke them.  But fast forward a bit. Within a week, Cybertruck had won over many of its fiercest detractors. Over 250,000 people were so enamored they were willing to deposit a hundred dollars to be among its first potential owners. So, how do Musk and co. do it? How do they manage to build products that customers are dying to get their hands on? Musk revealed the answer to that question in a recent interview: "A lot of times I think people try to make products that they think others would love but they don't love them themselves. If you don't love the product, you should not expect that others will." (Read more in today's column.) #Tesla   #ElonMusk   #Cybertruck   #innovate   #disrupt   #leadership   #management   #BusinessAdvice   #EmotionalIntelligence   #EQApplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

What and how you share your wisdom matters. Ask yourself if you‚Äôre committing these common  #thoughtleadership  sins: 1. You only share the wins Nothing is a bigger turnoff than someone who is continuously boasting. People respond to those who are genuine and admit when they‚Äôve made a mistake. 2. You push your product or service Don‚Äôt make the mistake of using your platform for blatant self-promotion. Instead, provide value by serving, not selling.  3. You try to cover too much ground Stick to those few areas where you are expert. When you stay within your wheelhouse, your audience sees you as the go-to person. 4. You never get to the point Meandering signals that you‚Äôre unorganized and unsure. Keep to one brief, compelling message. 5. You share haphazardly or infrequently Regularly and consistently publish your wisdom, so your network looks forward to‚Äîand trusts‚Äîyour insights and observations. 6. You post & ghost Merely posting isn‚Äôt enough; you want to start conversations and build relationships, so engage with those who engage with your posts. 7. You‚Äôre not telling a consistent career story People want to learn more about thought leaders. Create a cohesive, up-to-date and engaging presence that aligns with your content and supports your positioning. #personalbranding

See this new article on Princeton and women in leadership. I think it re-hashes what we know (mentoring matters) and misses culture change and self reflection.  My comment follows link:  https://lnkd.in/dTZf4wG I am struck by the total focus on mentoring for women; this is important to be sure and it is not new. What is striking is that there is almost no mention of institutional culture and the need to change that. How important is it to create an environment in which women can thrive as leaders. Were I to institute a look-see at Princeton, I would look at culture first -- what is it in the culture that enables men to seek and thrive in leadership posts. Hard to look inward and admit that there may be cultural biases and impacts and auras. Hard to face a male dominated past and current culture. Hard to be honest about what is inhibiting success. Mentoring matters for real. But, it is not enough. No indeed.

Recently, I shared a report that stated: "It takes roughly seven patients presenting after an abnormal pulse alert to establish one clinically actionable cardiovascular diagnosis." I described that you cannot expect one digital health technology to solve a medical issue in itself. And you cannot avoid using such technologies in healthcare to provide sufficient care. This is why digital health is a cultural transformation where you can't just drop a technology into the system and expect everything to get better. You need both patients and medical professionals to be on the same page, discuss the expectations and side effects and work together by using that technology. This is the topic that we address in the newest article on  The Medical Futurist .  #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology

Today we are publishing an interim edition of Sarah Jeong's 'The Internet of Garbage' available for free download on  theverge.com . Sarah recently left The Verge to join The New York Times and was almost immediately subjected to an astonishing vitriolic attack by right wing trolls. I found it genuinely horrifying to read the death threats (and far worse) directed at a colleague I knew to be anything but the racist she was inaccurately being portrayed as. Sarah, of course, dealt with it grace and humor telling me that at least the trolls were using a decent photo of her. The irony of course is that in her book (first published in 2015) is a seminal work outlining just how online harassment works. You should read it.  https://lnkd.in/dnbMHrq

The absence of a concession by Trump is but one of the difficult issues our students need to process and understand.  I just published a free download for educators on how to discuss the election in a non-partisan way. Once the concession issues are unfolded and addressed, I will add more to the list of teaching tools. I have also recognized that in a world of online learning, some of my books need to be made available as PDFs. That now includes the Tongue Twister book and the Lady Lucy Laugh Giraffe book, both of which are trauma responsive. They can be found at  https://lnkd.in/eaWQeJ6 .  In terms of resources, there is also a Trauma Toolbox How To Guide and The Feeling Alphabet Activity Set, also available at a reasonable price on my website. Finally, I am working on a Holiday Kit -- a type of trauma responsive bag that will help children and families navigate the inevitable changes of the coming holiday season (no Santa's lap; no in person caroling in close proximity.  Please access these resources.  Our children need them -- the amount of trauma is real and not declining.

Despite the upbeat news on the vaccines, I think we are struggling mightily across the nation with three key issues: (1) Pandemic fatigue including Zoom fatigue; (2) Absence of interpersonal touch and connectivity; and (3) Upcoming holidays and "tradition" changes that distance us.  In a sense, the second "surge" feels, at least to some of us, worse than the first surge; the numbers are perilously high; we have a dysfunctional transition of power (whatever your political persuasion) that is harming our nation. Some of us have become more isolated than perhaps even necessary due to fear as others flaunt mandates and best practices.   In a sense, we are unaccustomed and unprepared for what is happening in our nation.  We can rightly ask: how do we move forward with grace and wisdom and perspective?  What compensatory mechanisms can we deploy to help all those who need help? And, what about our children and their ability to navigate forward?   I have one thought: I have hope.  I still believe despite some evidence to the contrary that people are decent and caring and at the end of the day, the better side of humanity and the wiser voices will rise to the top and be seen and heard.  I still have hope.   Do you? 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

GOOD OR BAD: MONOGAMY  Having strong opinions are like a disease. You get one, then your friends get the same one (else, according to the rules of groupthink they are no longer friends) and so on.  I hate opinions. There always seems to be someone smarter than me who has the opposite opinion.  But I'm skeptical. And I like to know things. And think. And learn. And study. AND be entertained. And laugh.  I'm launching a new podcast soon with my friend and bestselling author, AJ Jacobs called "GOOD or BAD". We take topics: Dogs, Monogamy, Cars, Government, Billionaires, Tipping, Democracy, Cosmetic surgery, etc and argue:  "Is this good or bad?"  Sometimes we have a conclusion. Sometimes not.  Here is a teaser for one of the episodes: GOOD or BAD: Monogamy.  If you have suggestions for "good or bad" topics, please let me know in the comments.  Or, if you have opinions on monogamy, leave them in comments and I hope we read out some comments in the episode.  Enjoy! #podcast   #monogamy   #dating   #polyamory   #podcast   #opinions

Someone should coin "the law of 2020".  It means if you post something positive these days, people try hard to find the negative.  If you dare try and laugh, people will scald you. If you share good news, people will point to privilege or bad news to counteract it. Any wonderful data point is met with " yeah but what about XXXX"  If you point out the huge signs of progress in the world, people will point out your ignorance. It's driven by the media, and their accidental ( and unacknowledged addiction to cheap clicks, which play to misery and fears)  Its distorted our sense of the world, it's genuinely blinded the media to any positivity and algorithms neutralize the ability of good or reassuring news to spread.  It's like a giant self righteous woke festival of misery, a competition to be more anxious, more pious.  There is zero evidence life should be lived in a serious manner. We are all going to die. We can fight for change and justice and for better, and maybe without being so god dam miserable and judgmental and serious. It's not some giant competition to self flagellate with self imposed misery, unless I missed the "this is life in 2020" email.

TL;DR: Bravo, Microsoft. Well done!! Nine years ago, I remember having a conversation with a (now-departed) Microsoft executive about the future of Windows Phone. My take was that we would be better off monetizing Office for Mac and Android by making it available on the hundreds of millions of devices already being sold. I distinctly remember saying: "We already own the office productivity market for Desktop, this is the easiest way to win in Mobile - right now. We can fight the hardware battle another day." Emphatically, I was told that I was wrong, without any data to back up that assertion, other than, and I quote: "We will kill the iPhone."  Years later, $40+ billion wasted on Nokia, many lessons learned, we now have this: "But Microsoft has assured CNET that it's sticking with Android and has no plans to make a Windows-based phone. The company's Chief Product Officer Panos Panay was so emphatic about that fact, he told Wired so -- twice" What a tremendous cultural change by Microsoft. Where Steve Ballmer and many of his former leaders fanatically pushed a dying idea to the brink of despair, Satya Nadella smartly monetized Office, embraced the world's biggest phone OS, and quietly beat everyone to innovation. This is how you win. 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

We‚Äôve seen it coming but now it‚Äôs here: smart apps that are replacing-or displacing-the need for doctor‚Äôs visits! And there is probably more displacement than just doctor's visits‚Äînow Alexa can tell if your breathing is raspy due to a cold or pneumonia! It can tell if your child is autistic, it can be your post-hospital ‚Äòvisiting nurse,‚Äô it can order your medicines when you are running low...it can comfort lonely seniors and let kids with cancer talk to other kids with cancer about their medical journey. Ok‚Äîit can‚Äôt do all this...yet...but very, very soon. And all these medical capabilities are accomplished via AI and machine learning systems--and whether it is to differentiate cardiac pain from indigestion these home monitoring devices are providing to be highly accurate‚Äîmore than doctors would be. So, welcome your new Doctor/Nurse Alexa. Selected Excerpt: ‚ÄúThese devices correctly identified agonal breathing in 97% of instances, while registering a false positive only 0.2% of the time...Alexa could send vitals to a doctor‚Äôs office before you head to your appointment and continue to monitor your condition after you get home.‚Äù

I can't tell you how proud and excited I'm now to share the newest e-book from  The Medical Futurist  with you. This time, we decided to try to tackle the beast: the issue of privacy in the digital health era. While the e-book focuses on practical recommendations and examples about YOUR privacy, it presents details on three levels: 1. Healthcare institutions holding on to your data (your medical records) 2. Medical data stored in the technologies you use (from fitness trackers to genetic tests) 3. Medical data stored where you aren‚Äôt aware of (from A.I. to the cloud) These three levels should be at the forefront of every privacy discussion going forward. They encompass the traditional, the new and the future spheres where our data is and will increasingly be stored. I truly hope you will find this e-book useful and I look forward to your feedback so we can keep on expanding it. #ebook   #privacy   #digitalhealth   #medicaldata   #healthcare   #futureofhealthcare   #healthtech   #themedicalfuturist

The new key factors candidates will look for in their next job post-corona. Pre-corona candidates decided to sign with companies based on 4 key factors: daily commute, the people, the role, and of course, money. Companies actually developed techniques and selling points in order to sell the positions based on these factors, and now we have a game-changer!  After some research on my side, I can tell that things are gonna change. Here are the new 4 key factors that will be considered in the post-corona era: **Financial stability of the company (the company fired staff during corona, or sent employees to unpaid leave) **Work-life balance (did the company take into consideration work hours for employees with kids, WFH)  **Social responsibility (companies that helped during the corona with donations, volunteering, and technology)  **A place to stay for the long term (according to salary, perks, and people). WDYT? What will be the new key-factors? (In the picture AppsFlyer Cares van came to cheer up our medical heroes). AppsFlyer  #covid19

In Case You Missed It: Life Saving Medicine Now (Sorta) Affordable Good News: Insulin is now only going to cost people in Colorado $100.00/month, regardless of what the insurance companies or pharmaceutical companies or middlemen want to charge patients.  (According to many sources, the cost of insulin has tripled in the last three years costing patients $6,000.00 per year!) Bad News: This is still really expensive for a lot of people ‚Äîthat‚Äôs $1,200.00 per year! Especially since over 100 million Americans have diabetes!  Good News: Even though you have to be a resident of Colorado to benefit from this cap, it‚Äôs a strong start and a model for all other states. Let‚Äôs hear it for common sense and great legislation. 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

Great to talk with Fox Business today on why companies should invest in Apprenticeship ?  I know many people reading this have already invested and they see the returns first hand every day.  Love to hear your experience.  For those considering taking on an apprentice or starting a program - here is some compelling reasons to give it a go... Firstly, an apprenticeship  program is one of the best investments a firm can make - U.S. Department of Labor statistics show that companies with apprenticeship programs earnt a return on investment of $1.46 for each dollar invested.  That is an average - in some sectors the ROI has been estimated at as much as $11 for every dollar invested !   Apprenticeship programs also provide employers with opportunities to improve workplace productivity, improve workforce diversity and build a pipeline of workers with the precise skills needed in your workplace (now and into the future). They can help shape the employee to your workplace culture and can strengthen your brand as an employer of choice; and finally boost employee retention.   #apprenticeship Watch:

Students in Darwin in Australia‚Äôs Top End will gain valuable real-world skills in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), thanks to the Pathways in Technology (P-TECH) Australia program. Exciting that Casuarina Senior College in Darwin is the first P-TECH in the Northern Territory. P-TECH is an innovative model of collaboration between education and industry and will provide an industry supported pathway for young people in the NT and build the skills they need for the jobs of the 21st century. Maritime and defence industries are growing quickly in the NT so the Australian Industry and Defence Network will be a key partner on this P-TECH. I was pleased to join the conversation at the inagural planning meeting with energized employers and educators at Casuarina Senior College last week. The first P-TECH school was established in the US by  IBM  in 2011 in collaboration with the New York City Department of Education, The City University of New York, and the New York City College of Technology. IBM is the industry partner for the Ballarat Federation College Partnership. #STEM Jade Moffat Herman ¬† Amy-Lou Cowdroy-Ling ¬† Janine McPhee ¬† Nathan Ellery ¬† Rashid Ferrod Davis ¬† Sharna Peters ¬† Louise Davis

I‚Äôm actually jealous  It doesn‚Äôt happen often, and never when talking about medicine or healthcare, but I‚Äôm jealous of those citizens who are already receiving the COVID-19 vaccination. So says the first recipient: ‚ÄúI can finally look forward to spending time with my family and friends in the new year after being on my own for most of the year.‚Äù That‚Äôs the feeling I want to have‚Äîjoy, relief, self-respect and duty to my country.  Good behavior with mask wearing and good citizenship are normal parts of my behavior when it comes to COVID-19, and it takes effort‚ÄîI‚Äôve got my many masks on me all the time, hand sanitizer handy. I‚Äôm weighing going (and not going) to stores, movies, not hugging friend, not going into their homes and on it goes. And I‚Äôll keep doing all of these things but it is getting harder to do‚ÄîI mean who doesn‚Äôt want to have a cozy meal with friends? I trust science and medicine‚Äîover the last 150 years, modern healthcare has done more to improve our lifespan than any other factors‚Äîclean water, clean sanitation, antibiotics, vaccinations, dental health, are the cornerstone to our collective health and why we now live past the age of 50. So when my time comes to get vaccinated, I‚Äôll put on my Sunday Best, roll-up my sleeve and proudly get injected. 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

üõë STOP quitting when you win ‚Äî go until you can‚Äôt go anymore. üõë  I was talking to one of my business coaches and he was explaining his wife‚Äôs mindset as a D1 high jumper.  - Every win she ever had ended in 3 subsequent failures. - She didn‚Äôt stop when she beat the rest of the competition. She stopped when she could no longer jump over the next height. I was a collegiate triple jumper so I totally resonate with that. And it‚Äôs shaped my mindset as an entrepreneur. Work every day to put yourself out of business. Push yourself. I‚Äôm not okay with being the best. I want to dominate, leave a legacy, and be the best version of me. What about you? #justQ  üññüèΩüñ§

content: How to Make Friends, According to Science

When steam engines were invented, despite directly producing incredible amounts of rotary force, for about the first 20 years they were used primarily to pump water uphill to drive water wheels. This is the mistake made with most digital transformation. We make the least imaginative change, the fastest, least risky and easiest to get through accounting alteration,¬† by bolting on the new to what we have.¬† Next time you see a process with new technology ponder this. Are we adding new technology like oil, or rebuilding around the power of the new. It's 99% the former. This is all in my book. 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

So proud of  Melissa Bosworth , one of  The Aspen Institute 's 2020 Healthy Communities Fellows I've been supporting during this insane year. Melissa is an Assistant Professor at  Regis University  in Denver and Executive Director of the  Eastern Plains Healthcare Consortium . She's an expert on  #healthcare  administration and on  #ruralhealth . But Melissa is also a mother and a wife who's caring for her own ailing elderly mother during a pandemic --while holding three jobs. Melissa wrote a beautiful "love letter" to  #caregivers  during the era of  #COVID19 , and it's been published by  The Denver Post . I'm so pleased to see the Healthy Communities fellows amplify their voices during these tense times, even as they navigate their own complex commitments and obligations. Read Melissa's story below. #cancersupport   #caregiving   #selfcare

As part of its strategy to adapt to post-pandemic times, Walmart is making some major changes to the way it runs its Supercenters: The company is introducing a new team-based operating model--and giving pay raises to tens of thousands of employees. The new model, which has already been tested at Sam‚Äôs Club and Walmart Neighborhood Market stores, includes the following: -Cross-training small teams of associates, who can then better support during busy shifts or support associates who take time off  -New leadership roles, both at the salaried and hourly level -A new pay structure and higher pay for team leads and about 165,000 hourly employees Of course, there‚Äôs no way to know in advance how well Walmart will execute on its new plans. But the basic blueprint sends a great message to employees, one that's founded on sound business strategy and emotional intelligence: People over tasks.  Breadth over depth.  Don‚Äôt just tell, show. (Read more in today's column.) #walmart   #emotionalintelligence   #criticalthinking   #leadership   #management   #eqapplied #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

While I write often about the limitations of artificial intelligence and what it can really offer in practice today, sometimes I come across developments in A.I. that not only blow my mind away but also depict an exciting vision of the future of healthcare. Look at this: In some cases, patients need injections with an iodine-based dye (radiocontrast) to make their organs more visible in scans. But some patients can‚Äôt take the dye. So researchers developed a GAN (generative adversarial network) that generates labeled, undyed CT images of lesions on kidneys, spleens, and livers. They added these images to real-world training data to improve performance of a segmentation model that marks lesions in diagnostic scans. As it's really hard to get enough quality medical data to train the algorithm on and labeled medical data is even harder to find, GANs are making it easier and less expensive to create large, annotated datasets for training A.I. diagnostic tools.   #artificialintelligence   #ai   #aihealthcare   #digitalhealth   #futureofhealthcare   #themedicalfuturist 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

Are you honest? Have you ever told a lie? You see the problem. We all think we are honest, yet we have all done things that are dishonest. We can rationalize our actions, ‚Äúit‚Äôs just a little white lie,‚Äù or ‚Äúyeah, but it didn‚Äôt matter.‚Äù Dr. Lenny Wong has spent years studying ‚Äúethical fading,‚Äù when organizations and individuals make unethical decisions believing they haven‚Äôt done anything wrong. What‚Äôs astounding is how pervasive it is. In this week‚Äôs episode of A Bit of Optimism, we talked about what ethical fading is and what we can do about it. 2008 and 2018. I was 23 on the left and just starting my company, Zen Media. I‚Äôd just finished graduate school and writing my thesis on Twitter. No one believed social media would be a field. It was early (...very early) days. I could have never imagined the highs and lows which would follow. The following year, Business Week would name me to their 25 under 25 entrepreneurs list. Inc and Forbes would follow suit in the years to come...In the 10 years to follow, I‚Äôd write two best selling books. The Zen of Social Media Marketing (4th edition now) and Momentum. Zen Media would grow to be a globally known marketing firm with an enviable client list. I‚Äôd keynote at hundreds of events in front of thousands. I‚Äôd learn what it means to lead people and make a ton of mistakes in the process. I‚Äôd know great love and great loss. But, I‚Äôd find that in the depth of winter lay within me an invincible summer. And, I‚Äôd learn the most important lesson of all - be grateful for your highs and graceful in your lows. üíû #10yearchallenge

Who is Responsible For Our Old People? While riding public transit today I ran across this elderly man who was displaying clear signs of dementia and appeared disheveled. He posed no risk to himself or others. Not sure if he was on his way to or from somewhere. Not sure if anyone wondered when he‚Äôd arrive or worried if he didn‚Äôt show up.  He seemed utterly alone, which seems painful given his senior years and confused state. Maybe we don‚Äôt (collectively) care...but somehow it struck a sad cord in my heart as I watched him point to no one and talk to no one. At one point in time, he was someone‚Äôs child and might be someone‚Äôs father. Where are people like this supposed to live? Who is supposed to help them. Where is our humanity‚Äîand even absent that‚Äîwhere is our infrastructure which should exist in a democratic society which holds that all people are created equal and deserves compassion? 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

Well, another quandary with respect to which I need some insight.  I just read the stories about the predator/ cult leader Larry Ray and his involvement with students at Sarah Lawrence College (including his own daughter).  It took a while but he was just arrested (later than necessary). The NYMagazine piece is chilling. My questions do not relate to the power of a cult figure on young people.  We have many examples of this... sadly. Here‚Äôs what I don‚Äôt get:  where were the Sarah Lawrence administrators and staff? Apparently, at least one knew something was ‚Äúup‚Äù in a specific dorm and did not address the issues.  Perhaps a parent can spend a night or two or three in a dorm but Larry Ray‚Äôs stay appears to be much longer.  Didn‚Äôt folks notice?  Wasn‚Äôt there an RA?  I frankly am hard pressed to believe the College could claim to be so hands off or ignorant or accepting of parents living on campus. Weren‚Äôt red lights flashing? Lives and relationships were ruined.  What responsibility did/does Sarah Lawrence have and are the personnel then there  still employed?  Years in question seem to be 2010 ‚Äî 2014.   There must be another piece or two of three that I am missing.  I have known some administrators there ‚Äî remarkable people. Explain to me what happened please.

Here I am again cheerleading for an "Outsider" to come to Healthcare's aide!  I've been a consistent advocate for new entrants with bold ideas driven by creative, optimistic leaders, to provide CPR!  Like Apple and Amazon. My belief is that  "The Healthcare Institutional Mindset"  (including hospitals, nursing facilities and delivering systems) is one which is fundamentally risk-adverse, backwards-thinking and myopic.  Within these organizations you will not find "skunk works" or "innovation labs" or "stealthy teams" working on new approaches to patient care. In healthcare we are designed (and hire) for being slow, cautious and repetitious ... even if doing the same thing over and over leads to the same mediocre and disappointing results. Again I say "Apple, come find me! I'm just up the road and am here to help improve care delivery for patients !" Selected excerpt: "The iPhone, which turned 10 this summer, already aggregates some health data in apps. But most of that is patient-generated. If the company can add information from doctors offices and clinics‚Äîtest results, visit summaries, medication lists‚Äîthe iPhone could become an important healthcare tool in achieving interoperability, which has for so long frustrated the industry."

I just watched The American Meme documentary on Netflix and it should be a cautionary tale for all of us who share our lives online. Before, content was the king. Now it's just pure attention.  What I learnt here is not that being an influencer with millions of followers without any "traditional" content or quality is bad. What I learnt that for all of us who discuss health, technology and science online, we need to learn how to get quality attention, not just how to provide quality content.  If you have a favorite online influencer in any topic you like to follow, please share which one and why.

Coping when you get sick or injured‚Äîit‚Äôs tough. My husband came home yesterday in a cast after tearing his Achilles‚Äô tendon. And he was very irked and cranky.  Every day people break bones, sprain ankles, get diagnosed with pneumonia, chicken pox, get their hip replaced and many other ailments that require people ‚Äústaying put‚Äù for a week or three. So what‚Äôs the best way to move past being mad or irritated or depressed during a period of injury or illness? Step one. Accept the current reality of the situation. Step two? Reframe the situation‚ÄîFor example if you are ‚Äòbummed out‚Äô you can‚Äôt play tennis for three months, think  ‚Äònow an opportunity to read those books I‚Äôve been wanting to read‚Äô or to ‚Äòlearn to cook those four dishes that I‚Äôve  just haven‚Äôt gotten around to...‚Äô Truth is there‚Äôs lots that can be done during this ‚Äòdown time,‚Äô so think ‚ÄòCrisis as Opportunity.‚Äô 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

Yesterday, I gave a keynote about artificial intelligence's role in healthcare to a biopharma company. One of the best questions I received was about liability. Who is to blame if an A.I. algorithm makes a mistake? This is a recurring issue and I like to answer it with a metaphor. If a physician listens to your heart sounds with a stethoscope and there was something wrong with the device and it misled the diagnosis, who is to blame? The manufacturer of the stethoscope? Never. The physician is supposed to be using all the available technologies at their disposal and with their expertise and knowledge therefore only they can be blamed, the final decision is their responsibility.  The same applies to the use of A.I. It is a (regulated, supervised and assessed) tool in the physician's hand and thus only contributes to the decisions, not making them.  What do you think? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

How many influential business leaders have you seen nix a little bit of fun as a waste of time and energy? This article from  The New York Times  is a refreshing reminder that "guilty-pleasures" are good for you. ‚ÄúA guilty pleasure is something that we enjoy, but we know we‚Äôre either not supposed to like, or that liking it says something negative about us. That negative thing often ends up being an association with categories of identity we disparage and marginalize in society.  Consider what separates sports and reality TV.  The idea of someone apologizing for watching the NBA finals sounds silly, but the implied apology when someone says, ‚ÄúUgh, I know ‚ÄòThe Bachelor is awful but I can‚Äôt stop watching it‚Äù is normalized." The Journal of Media Psychology conducted a study proving that playing a video game or watching a movie or television can restore some psychological resources and reduce stress. ü¶Ñ‚ú®ü¶Ñ Yesterday I indulged in lemon bars, the purchase of a jacket covered in rainbow sequins, wearing my favorite pair of unicorn slippers while watching Dynasty on Netflix.  #NoGuilt ü¶Ñ‚ú®ü¶Ñ BONUS READ Pleasure Activism: The Politics of Feeling Good #MentalHealth   #Leadership   #Happiness   #ChantelShares

With so many out of work, I thought I'd re-share this piece I wrote on using the "laddering" technique to understand what underlying skills you actually have. Self-assessment can be hard. When we look at "what we do" we tend to get stuck in the definitions of the roles and the industry we are in. By "laddering," and getting to those underlying skills, you can start to see that many if not all are truly applicable to other jobs and even other industries. While not a cure-all, I hope this helps. #evaluation   #skillsets   #laddering   #unemployement   #unemployed   #employmentstrategies   #hr   #humanressources   #jobseeking   #jobhuntingtips

Physical retail was broken long before the pandemic accelerated its decline. So, thinking that consumers will ‚Äúgo back‚Äù to what used to define the physical retail experience means believing that consumers will want to do more of what many had already decided they wanted to do less of: shop in the physical store. The only thing holding many consumers back from abandoning physical retail was inertia, something that the pandemic has motivated consumers to overcome. Now that they have there‚Äôs no turning back.

She told me: ‚Äúa young girl came in the other day, who saw the badge earlier that week, so she was brave enough to come in and show me the pictures she took with her phone on her urticaria that only comes in the morning. The patient also told me about how she googled her symptoms but couldn‚Äôt find any reasonable explanation. She was happy about the badge because she has mixed experiences of googling and interpreting it to healthcare practitioners. I think it‚Äôs a great possibility to get closer to younger generations because she felt safe and understood, so she won‚Äôt be hesitating next time she has any problem‚Äù. It was really hard to track down the developers of Leela Chess Zero, the highest rated chess engine today, but I managed to find them in a developer forum. It was interesting to learn that the developers are not professional chess players and they don't even need to be to develop such an algorithm.  Imagine the same in medicine. Developers creating the highest rated medical algorithm without having a profound knowledge of medicine. This is the era artificial intelligence is bringing to us. Here is how they described the algorithm works: "Leela Chess uses a neural network trained without human knowledge. The training procedure uses reinforcement learning to train the next generation of the network based on games played using the previous one against itself (‚Äúself-play‚Äù) so without any external influence. The initial network is trained using random games so there is no human input in the process. The next network improvement comes from using a (small) search tree to improve the neural network‚Äôs evaluation of a position and using this outcome, together with the game result, to train the next network. Any principles used during play are discovered this way, but not in a way that can be easily extracted as such. Obviously, the rules of chess are hard-coded in the engine." 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

Here are 24 suggestions* to help you leap into a better career:   1. Let it go Let go of those people and things that support your history, not your destiny.   2. Embrace progress over perfection Reframe failure as an opportunity to learn and take action to combat your perfectionism.   3. Build in time to reflect Slow down, stop multitasking, let your mind wander, and pay attention to what bubbles up.   4. Focus on upping your ‚Äúknow, like, trust‚Äù factor Share your insights, listen more, and treat people with kindness and respect.   5. Just say ‚Äòno‚Äô Say no if it doesn‚Äôt excite you, speak to your values, further your mission in life, or help you achieve your goals.   6. Try saying ‚Äòyes‚Äô Say yes to new challenges and opportunities, invite collaboration, empower and affirm others, and create an environment where it‚Äôs safe to try, fail, learn and innovate.   7. Brush up on your soft skills Use soft skills to create environments that empower and ignite teams, delight customers, and fuel sustainable growth.   8. Master time-management Do, decide, delegate or delete tasks, eliminate distractions, embrace mono-tasking, work your own rhythms, and build in breaks to recharge.   *Part 1 of 3   #career   #leadership   #progress 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

The  FDA ‚Äôs new A.I. action plan just got published. Here are the main points: 1. Tailored Regulatory Framework My take: As the draft guidance about this with details will come out this year, I hope adaptive algorithms will be covered. 2. Good Machine Learning Practice My take: The FDA wants to harmonize such practices across a range of international organizations. I'm not sure it‚Äôs possible, since their detailed plan is still not ready. 3. Patient-Centered Approach My take: I would‚Äôve expected the digital health arm of the FDA to appoint a patient engagement advisory board, as promoting a patient centric approach without actively involving patients sounds like a risky business. 4. Regulatory Science Methods Related to Algorithm Bias & Robustness My take: This is why we expected that the FDA would take over our open access database of A.I.-based medical devices that we published in Nature Publishing Group's npj Digital Medicine paper. However, they confirmed to me that they won‚Äôt. 5. Real-World Performance  My take: The FDA should promote the importance of prospective studies when it comes to analyzing algorithms' performance in medical tasks.

Every single day, more than 150,000 of our beloved American friends and family members are getting infected. And every single day 1,200 friends and family members are dying. It‚Äôs sobering and it‚Äôs scary. But those of us that have the strength of body and mind can help reduce the fear, and help reduce the spread of this Killer (COVID-19) by showing their love and neighborliness by wearing a mask and keeping some distance‚Äîeven during these times of gatherings.  (After all, a mask is just a mask...just like a broken arm needs a cast, it‚Äôs just a cast...) In a world where external demands and a cacophony of noise bombard us, taking the time to turn inward and think deeply may be the ultimate luxury‚Äîand the best way to figure out what‚Äôs next in your  #career .   Here‚Äôs how:   Be intentional with your time Treat reflection as essential to your  #careerdevelopment  by scheduling time to think.   Slow down & stop multitasking It‚Äôs impossible to think deeply and carefully about your future while you‚Äôre multitasking. Slow down to find clarity among your chaos.   Eliminate distractions Up your odds for reflection success by turning off notifications, silencing your phone, and closing down tabs.   Get up & out(side) Research says walks in nature enhance brain function, reduce stress, keep you energized, and improve creativity, which enables better reflection.   Allow your mind to wander During reflection, try not to limit yourself to predetermined topics, or impose any rigid standards.   Pay attention to what bubbles up Use your self-awareness to pay attention to how you‚Äôre feeling, your reactions, and any new ideas that arise during reflection.   Record & review your thoughts so you can take action Until you capture your thoughts and goals, you‚Äôll never be able to devise a plan of action to achieve them.   #leadership 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

Without trust, there can be no love, no friendship, no lasting connection between people.¬†But where there is trust, there is motivation to act.¬† If you trust someone is looking after your best interests, you will do almost anything that person asks of you.¬† So, how can you build trust? By doing the following: 1. Listen 1st. 2. Show empathy. 3. Be authentic. 4. Set the example. 5. Be helpful. 6. Disagree and commit. 7. Be humble. 8. Be transparent. 9. Commend sincerely and specifically. Of course, some of these are easier said than done. How can you build these qualities into your daily habits? And companies, how can you build this into your organizational culture? Read the answer in my¬†new book, "EQ Applied: The Real-World Guide to Emotional Intelligence":  https://amzn.to/2sxFLho #EmotionalIntelligence¬†#empathy¬†#leadership¬†#management¬† #BestAdvice¬†#careers¬†#BusinessIntelligence¬†#communication #EQApplied¬†#MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

I quit corporate life 7 years ago with some cash in the bank...I thought I would travel around the world for a year or take a two year break.  Instead, I've been learning about media and dabbling in creating content. I cover the serious topic of finance but I don't take myself too seriously. I have fun making the content. (Pic is from latest shoot in Goa!) I cover my costs such that I still have the original cash in the bank as my emergency cash fund. I say I am retired. People argue with me saying I still work...that's not retirement. Ok, call it what you will. Around the same time, someone coined financially independent, retire early (FIRE). Fine by me. Work has radically changed. It's time to embrace it. When you equip and empower your employees to adapt and find the tools they need to be effective and efficient it is an investment in your company‚Äôs present and future profitability.  Recently I worked with the largest independent Coca-Cola distributor in the United States. Their remote sales team worked hard, nights and weekends and rarely took time off.  However, sales call volume and sales numbers were down. Morale had plummeted. Paperwork, emails, phone calls, and unmet goals were piling up. Management realized that their team members were frantically busy, but not terrifically productive.  We worked with the sales team members, managers, and the sales leadership team and boosted productivity and performance. As a result, the remote sales team's  total sales calls per week went up over 20% from the prior year, which translated into $2 million in additional revenue.  Embrace the new world of work and make an investment in your company‚Äôs long-term growth and profitability.

What can you do when doctor shortages do not allow a country to provide care for everyone? You send out junior doctors to rural regions without any major experience. This is where artificial or augmented intelligence can jump in.  A Chinese company, RXThinking, is training medical algorithms to become super-diagnostician that can be dispatched to all corners of China. Instead of replacing physicians with algorithms, RXThinking's A.I.-based diagnosis app empowers them because it acts like a navigation app for the diagnostic process, drawing on all available knowledge to recommend the best route but still letting the physicians control the decision-making process. Just one example how and why A.I. is crucial for solving healthcare's global issues. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

Waiting on pins and needles, going crazy figuring out how to dress for the interview or how to wear your hair... Intimidated by body language and unexpected questions during the in-person interrogation, that makes your stomach flip... When I applied for a job as a Marketing Manager for an IT academy I was invited for an interview, One of the six people interviewing me started to pick on me for using the word "dazzled" in my cover letter. It was totally on brand,  But this engineer didn't dig that flavor or my bubbly nature, regardless of skill. Right then I knew it wasn't a fit. Needless to say, I went from having dreams of working for a small IT academy to writing for Thrive Global, working for millionaires across the globe on how to amplify their personal brand and thought influence. A lot has changed over the years. And I still use the word "dazzled" wherever possible üòâ Never dull your flavors to fit into someone else's recipe, especially when seeking a fit in your career. If you're looking for ways to build a culture that attracts and retains top talent, read my love story... #Culture   #Inclusion   #Success

Some folks think  Netflix  launched streaming fully formed. The reality is that when streaming launched, nothing about it could be considered "great." The streaming quality wasn‚Äôt there and the library of titles available to watch was sub-par. Which is why it was launched as a free add-on for subscribers. Also, at-launch, you could only watch via a PC. Then, eventually a Mac. But the challenge the company faced was how to tap into the TV. Smart TVs and internet-connected DVD players were not widespread. Enter gaming consoles. Why? Because the goal was to get Netflix on as many internet-connected devices as quickly as possible. And game consoles already had installed user bases in the tens of millions and their consoles were all connected to the internet. So Netflix partnered with  Microsoft  XBOX,  Sony  PS3, and, believe it or not,  Nintendo  Wii. This was a mock-up of the sticker used on XBOX360 LIVE Gold physical packaging from 2008. Note the title count (12,000) and the rarely defined free trial duration. This was before the move to a 1-month free trial. #streaming   #netflix   #microsoft   #nintendo   #sony   #ps3   #xbox   #wii   #streaminghistory   #OTT   #netflixhistory 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

It‚Äôs Finally Here: Machines As Doctor and  Diagnostician  Researchers found that deep learning algorithms correctly detected disease in 87% of cases, compared to 86% for healthcare professionals. Wow. Many of us who follow ‚Äòdeep learning‚Äô and AI markets have seen this in radiological images (X-rays), and now there is evidence that machine-based data accumulation can ‚Äòcrunch‚Äô and analyze information to provide better diagnoses than a doctor who has seen hundreds (or thousands) of patients with a similar disease or problem.  Think of what this can do to bring more reliable diagnoses to patients and, think about how such technologies can help patients in under-resourced areas get diagnosed and treated sooner. Talk about Democratizing health care! This is a huge leap forward for Public Health. Now....how do we get Humans to trust Machines?? Selected Excerpt: ‚Äú"Machines... can have a massive impact on problems in healthcare, big and small, but unless we can convince clinicians and the public of its safety and ability then it won't be much use to anybody..‚Äù 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

Drawing on scientific research and personal experience, authors and friends Lynne Everatt, Deb Mangolt, and Julie Smethurst created Acts of Friendship: a comprehensive, fun and hilarious how-to on overcoming disconnection in our increasingly isolating world. Divided into 47 activities to strengthen friendships old and new, Acts of Friendship is designed to give friends the time and space to reconnect with each other‚Äîas well as with their environment, their emotions and their values. Make a ‚Äúchuck-it‚Äù list of things you‚Äôll never do; go on and hike in order to let go of old grudges; communicate your gratitude through haiku. Embark on collective action to reduce your carbon footprint; luxuriate in chocolate facials to rebuke conventional beauty standards; discover your inner child by puzzling over an ‚Äúages eight and up‚Äù toykit; or host a ‚ÄúDinner of Truth‚Äù and lovingly confront your most annoying traits. In an era of individualism and isolation, Acts of Friendship is a powerful guide to unity and empathy, reminding us that only through deepening our bonds with both the people and the world around us can we arrive at lasting fulfillment  #actsoffriendship   #workplacewellbeing  .

Ten years ago, when a McKinsey consultant left the firm, chances were they headed toward a bank, private equity group, or another professional service firm‚Äîin London, New York, Berlin, or another big city. But as our firm changed more in the past decade than at any other time in its entire 96-year history, so did our alumni network. We‚Äôve integrated analytics, AI, digital, design, and other capabilities into the new ways we work with our clients. We‚Äôve opened new offices in 41 cities, many of which lie in emerging markets across Africa, Eastern Europe, and Southeast Asia. And we‚Äôve grown; McKinsey today is 30,000 colleagues strong. So today, that same consultant leaving our firm might launch a mobile healthcare service in India. Or develop self-driving cars in California. Or ‚Äì heading even farther afield, to the stratosphere ‚Äì lead a startup to clean up space debris.   #mckinsey   #careers   #professionalservices

Join Chantel Soumis and Jason Lebowitz as they continue their focus this week on Anxiety.  Anxiety is a normal and often healthy emotion. However, when a person regularly feels disproportionate levels of anxiety, it might become a medical disorder. Anxiety disorders form a category of mental health diagnoses that lead to excessive nervousness, fear, apprehension, and worry. Last week we began the conversation by talking about general anxiety.  Today's focus will be on Social Anxiety.  Social Anxiety is a chronic mental health condition in which social interactions cause irrational anxiety. For people with social anxiety disorder, everyday social interactions cause irrational anxiety, fear, self-consciousness, and embarrassment. Symptoms may include excess fear of situations in which one may be judged, worry about embarrassment or humiliation, or concern about offending someone. Come join in the discussion and leave your comments and questions.  The show streams live at 10 AM CST.

Here are five reasons why saying yes is one of the best decisions you can make for your career: 1. It opens you up to new challenges and opportunities. If you wait until you feel ready to pursue an opportunity, chances are it‚Äôll pass you by. Saying yes means that you‚Äôre open to moving past your comfort zone and embracing a new challenge.  2. It invites collaboration. There‚Äôs a reason improvisation is rooted in the phrase, ‚ÄúYes, and...‚Äù Unlike no, which shuts down conversations and progress, saying yes opens up positive possibilities and invites others to build together, fostering collaboration, partnership, and further discussion. 3. It empowers and affirms others. As a leader, choosing to say yes acts as an affirmation to others and their ideas: I hear what you just said. You‚Äôre paying attention, and they matter. And giving the green light signals trust, which empowers others. 4. It creates an environment where it‚Äôs safe to try, fail, learn, and innovate. When you freely say yes, you create a risk-tolerant environment. You encourage innovation by trying new things and using the successes and failures as learning opportunities. 5. It makes life more fun. Saying yes can bring you new sources of joy and lead you on an incredible adventure. #leadership   #career   #growth
