Empathy in founders is a highly underrated skill. And yet the best founders I have interviewed are deeply empathetic, often because they have had to overcome their own adversity. One such founder is the brilliant founder  David Rogier  of  MasterClass  who I had the pleasure of interviewing earlier this year. He said in his interview:  ‚ÄúI stutter. When I was a kid, it was bad. I was teased in school about it. My family refused to let me use it as an excuse. One day I decided to tell my grandfather that I stuttered and was being teased in school for it. He gave me a hug and said ‚Äî ‚ÄúSo? You going to let that stop you?‚Äù In his eyes, if you weren‚Äôt in Auschwitz‚Ä¶ you‚Äôre OK. My parents would not let me use my stutter as an excuse to temper my curiosity (to not ask questions). They always expected my brother and I, from a very early age, to participate in dinner conversations with their friends. They were incredibly loving and determined for my brother and I to achieve whatever we wanted.‚Äù  https://lnkd.in/em3TwNg   #founders   #startup   #entrepreneur   #entrepreneurship   #innovation   #tech

When I was 7 my parents and teachers didn't think I'd ever be able to read or do basic math, because of my debilitating dyslexia. I was lucky enough to work with an amazing educator who convinced me that my dyslexia was a superpower. My confidence grew, and I realized that the problem wasn't that I couldn't learn - it was that the standardized resources and tools being thrown at me were useless.  Once I was able to understand my dyslexia, I was able to master it and use it to my advantage. The same is true for ANY weakness. Get to know yourself. Get to know your faults. Then grab them by the horns, and use them to unleash your full potential.  Interviewer:  Bryan Elliott 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

I‚Äôm very pleased to share our new China Luxury Report 2019: How young Chinese consumers are reshaping global luxury My colleagues at McKinsey surveyed more than 1,000 young Chinese luxury consumers on what makes them tick, unlocking insights into their perceptions of luxury as a form of social capital that distinguishes them from peers in the world‚Äôs most populous nation. Our report suggests that by 2025, spending on luxury consumption in China will increase to 1.2 trillion RMB, in the process capturing 65% of additional global growth, and accounting for 40 percent of total global spending. For luxury brands selling high-end shoes, bags, fashion, jewelry, and watches, winning in China means nothing less than winning the global luxury race. https://lnkd.in/fXEJpa8 #mckinsey   #china   #luxury   #consumers   #socialcapital

Being in a new role as the Head of Product in a company that has so many exiting opportunities going on for it and that the roles of the product, design, and development are so key for its success, could be a lot to take on.  I'm having a great time getting a lot of super interesting work done at my new role at  Halo Neuroscience  such as defining Halo's products and experiences, establishing light processes to help our teams to be more effective, building teams, and getting  Halo Neuroscience  to the next stages. When I reflect back on how I gained my skills and learned some of the best practices I'm utilizing in my new role, I felt I owe a huge "THANK YOU" to a few of the product and design leaders I've worked with in the past and learned tremendously from. Thank you  Tim Roberts ,  Marianne Braunstein ,  Sumner Paine ,  Nick Myers ,  Jonathan O. , and  Ayse Kulahci . I'm putting a lot of the things I've learned from you into practice every day. I appreciate your leadership and mentorship throughout my career.  #mentorship   #leadership   #product   #productdevelopment   #productmanagement   #bestpractices   #buildingproducts   #teambuilding

I never had that Father figure growing up. And I‚Äôm not saying that to be down, I‚Äôve just never had that. As kids we looked out for one another. We did what we had to do to survive.  And for that I appreciate my dad. His absence taught us how to take care of ourselves. How to make shit happen on our own. How to survive. And I‚Äôm thankful for that. DeepMind  just made a nice gesture and shared its predictions about the protein structures of the coronavirus, which causes the COVID-19 epidemic.  The system uses a machine-learning technique known as "free modelling" to help it predict protein structures when no similar structures of protein are available. They decided not to wait for a peer-reviewed paper but published the results now.  They emphasised that "these structure predictions have not been experimentally verified, but hope they may contribute to the scientific community's interrogation of how the virus functions". A.I. in action. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #covid19   #coronavirus

It was great catching up with McKinsey's global managing director Dominic Barton in Hong Kong today.¬† I had the pleasure of working with Dominic back in his Shanghai days, when he led our Asia practice. In the nine years that he has led our firm, we've expanded into many innovative areas of client service, from data analytics, digital transformation, and design, to new business-building, implementation, and leadership development. We've also vastly expanded our reach into new locations around the world. Dominic has spearheaded the founding of Generation, an innovative program that places disconnected young adults in jobs, giving them the skills and support they need to achieve enduring personal and professional success. Since its creation in 2014, Generation has launched in 47 cities across 5 countries ‚Äì India, Kenya, Mexico, Spain, and the United States.¬† In total, more than 10,000 students have graduated and 84% of them have found jobs. You can find out more about the program here:¬† https://lnkd.in/fSbZQUE

I have been doing a lot of thinking lately about how the government spends money -- how it allocates its dollars (our dollars).  I have been struck by the no-bid Cerner contract with the VA to move to electronic health records which is estimated to cost $16 billion.  No typo.  See:  https://lnkd.in/e-bR3RW .   So, here's my question: What can you get for $16 billion if we had other spending priorities?  What disease could we cure for that amount?  Could we have universal early childhood education for that amount?  We have legislation with mandates that are unfunded; suppose we looked at some of those to fund?  A recent NY Times piece noted the proliferation of child pornography on the web and the absence of sufficient resources allocated to stomping out this problem. The legislation exists; the dollars don't. Bottom line: How can a private company get a $16 billion no bid contract when we have so many other needs?   Ask yourself: What can $16 billion buy? 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

The question about A.I. is never technology vs humans. GM Garry Kasparov introduced the concept of advanced chess, also known as cyborg or centaur chess. He wanted to bring together human and computer skills to achieve the following results: - increasing the level of play to heights never before seen in chess; - producing blunder-free games with the qualities and the beauty of both perfect tactical play and highly meaningful strategic plans; - offering the public an overview of the mental processes of strong human chess players and powerful chess computers, and the combination of their forces. The most exciting medical studies that used machine or deep learning did not conclude that algorithms are better than physicians at doing a specific task but those that showed how the combination of computational and human cognition leads to the best results.  My favorite studies in this are the ones with detecting breast cancer on slides and diabetic retinopathy on retinal images. Excellent results underscoring the notion that artificial narrow intelligence will work with medical professionals and vice versa for the best results.  Have you seen other similar studies concluding the same? Photo source:  Kasparov.com #digitalhealth   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #TMFchessjourney 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

Gary Vaynerchuk  says it's one of the biggest things to which he attributes his success.  Simon Sinek  believes it's the most important instrument in a leader's toolbox. And  Oprah Winfrey  cites it as fundamental to leadership. The secret of their success is something that might surprise you: EMPATHY. This soft skill is often misunderstood and confused with its cousin, sympathy, which is feeling compassion for somebody.   But empathy is about putting yourself in someone else‚Äôs shoes and seeing things from their perspective.   How can YOU be more a more empathetic leader?   First, shift your mindset to put people first. See them as human beings rather than a means to the end of a transaction or task.   Next, ask thoughtful and probing questions that draw out implications and feelings.   Finally, use your awareness to give others your full attention and truly listen to what matters most to them.   When you do these things, you‚Äôll better understand your customers, colleagues, and partners, and then be able to use those insights in ways to better serve and communicate with them.   And in this way, empathy can give you an edge as a leader‚Äîand as a human being.   #empathy   #leadership   #business   #success   #relationships   #communication   #growth   #softskills   #career   #HumansFirst   #growthmindset

The surge in emerging market bond issuance illustrates how Federal Reserve policies have opened wide the debt markets to those not having direct support. Per the data complied by Gramercy (thank you), the $327 billion in issuance YTD compares to $278 bn last year and $292 bn in 2018. The good news is that this massive bond issuance has allowed developing countries to avoid liquidity problems/other short-term problems turn into solvency/longer-term problems. Less good is the encouragement to cuspy (in terms of liquidity/solvency) borrowers to over-rely on debt financing. #markets   #debt   #em   #emergingmarkets   #fed   #centralbanks   #federalreserve   #gramercy  @gramercy

Here is what is worrying me (among other things): recommendation letters. There is a history of such letters being written for teachers to get new positions despite the fact that these teachers have abused students.  We often are less than honest (if omission counts) when we write letters of recommendation.  We assume receivers of letters can read between the lines and know that we are not truly recommending someone but we are being cautious to avoid charges of defamation, libel and other legal risks.   So, posit this hypothetical: write a recommendation letter for Bill O'Reilly.  What should it say? Would all references to sexual abuse/harassment be absent from such a letter?  Ponder this conundrum; recommendation letters are commonplace. 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

Stories need conflict. So ask yourself, what's the conflict in your life? Over the past few years I've gotten so comfortable at opening up and sharing my past. But I'm not so great at sharing what's going on currently (because I'm always so focused on getting through it). But that's something I'm working on as I move forward.  Because conflict is a gateway to connection. It makes your story relatable. That doesn't mean that everything you share has to be about hardship. Or that you need a rags to riches story.  But trickling in the adversity that your facing (or have faced) is a great way to take your content & story to the next level. Just something to think about. #justQ  üññüèΩüñ§

The essence of digital health from a recent paper of The Medical Futurist Institute: "Through the cultural transformation called digital health, the hierarchy of traditional medicine is transforming into an equal-level partnership between patients and caregivers. Besides many disruptive technologies, AI has the biggest potential to support this transition by analyzing the vast amounts of data patients and healthcare institutions record in every moment.  By taking away the repetitive parts of a physician‚Äôs job, it might lead to being able to spend more precious time with their patients, improving the human touch. However, AI can only fulfill its mission if it remains a safe, efficient, and proven aid in treating patients and improving healthcare." https://lnkd.in/gRGWDxt #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #TMFI   #research

From driverless taxis to automated cargo trucks, autonomous vehicles (AVs) will change the nature of on-road driving and, in the process, revolutionize the automotive and mobility industries. Within this mix of opportunity and uncertainty, we believe AV players (from components vendors to mobility service providers) could earn trillions in revenues in China. In the long term, China will likely emerge as the world‚Äôs largest market for autonomous vehicles. In fact, the Chinese automotive market is already adopting ‚Äúmobility-as-a-service‚Äù (MaaS) at a rapid rate. For example, cars sold to provide mobility services today represent about 10 percent of China‚Äôs total cars sales, and the country‚Äôs mobility-services market has grown at double-digit rates over the past several years. Read more about this topic in our latest report, "How China will help fuel the revolution in autonomous vehicles": https://lnkd.in/fH4cSai #automobiles   #cars   #China   #technology   #mobility

When  Netflix  launched streaming, it was only available on PCs. Then on Macs. Then game consoles (XBOX 360, PS3, Wii). Then came the opportunity to be available via  Apple TV. However, despite a back and forth between  Reed Hastings  and Steve Jobs, Jobs stuck to guns - no color logos on AppleTV.  It was too big of an opportunity to let get hung up by the desire to always use a full-color logo so I had the task of trying to figure out how to best represent it with those constraints.  These were the ideas I came up with. If I remember correctly, we ended up negotiating with Apple to either the 2nd or 4th one on the right. But in looking at this again, if you take away the box on the 3rd one on the left, it bears an odd resemblance to the logo as it is today. #Apple   #AppleTV   #Netflix   #logo   #design   #SteveJobs   #NetflixHistory   #netflixlogo   #brand

I just got back from San Diego, where the American Economic Association held its annual conference. I've been going to the meetings for close to a decade now, and this year's version looked and felt different. Job interviews (the conference doubles as a giant hiring fair) moved out of hotel rooms, where female candidates have long felt uncomfortable. There was an ombudsperson holding office hours to hear about harassment and abuse. There were even lines for the ladies room. In other words: Economics has made progress in the year since its longstanding problems with sexism and racism burst into public view. Many people told me they have seen the beginnings of a culture shift. And there have also been more concrete reforms: new committees, new policies, new enforcement mechanisms. But it is still unclear whether those reforms will translate into deeper, more lasting change. And in terms of hard numbers, economics has a long way to go: Gender and racial gaps in economics are wider -- and have been more stubborn -- than in many other fields. For more, see my story with  Jim Tankersley  and  Jeanna Smialek  in today's  The New York Times . #economics   #diversity   #gender   #race

Help me understand.¬† ¬†We have shootings in workplaces and that doesn't stop the way we treat violence and guns. We have shootings in an elementary school. Same outcome. We have shootings at a concert venue. Same outcome. We have shootings in churches (most recently in Texas). Same outcome. ¬†We have shootings on campuses. ¬†Same outcome. ¬† Safe places -- work, worship, schools -- are now unsafe. Why aren't we doing anything about guns and gun violence? ¬†Last time I checked, these guns were used to kill innocent people, not animals in the wild and not for self-protection. ¬†Without some change, we will not see change in the violence is protected places. What kind of world is that? Oh, we blame mental illness. ¬†Perhaps there has been mental diminution in those who have been the shooters. But, isn't there a link between access to weapons (their purchase and continued use) and gun violence? Might it be time to reconsider--finally --quality background checks, limits on numbers of purchases and a national database that works. What will it take? Post being shot, even Rep. Scalise was not against guns.

Have you ever been stuck in a rut? Have you felt like you can't get out of it, no matter how hard you try? When you are diagnosed with an incurable disease like cancer, it's easy to grieve and get stuck in a mental rut. Even as the "bubbly and blessed" I have felt my fair share of darkness fighting illness! We get out. We fight through the pain. We rise up and make the best of a very dark situation! Because the clouds WILL part üå© and the sun will come back out üåû Weathering the storm isn't about the cards you have in your hand... but about how you play the cards you've been dealt. That's why I stepped up to this challenge... AND I HAVE LEARNED A LOT! ‚úÖ I have been rejected over and over again... ‚úÖ Folks I NEVER thought would make a contribution showed up with extreme generosity... ‚úÖ While those I thought would give ignored my inquiry. And THAT'S OKAY. This is a big challenge, but I'm here to fight for the loved ones I've lost and know that as a parent, NO mother or father should EVER have to lose their baby to cancer. Let's cure it. This is my WHY for the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society  Please consider making a monetary or auction donation here:  https://lnkd.in/gdjKxAB #MWOY   #GiveBackChallenge   #Healthcare   #Gratitude

And for me it‚Äôs simple: am I outworking the old me? Am I better than the old me? Am I working towards the me that I want to be? At the end of the day there is no one on the planet with the same goals + plans as you. No point in competing with someone that‚Äôs playing a different game with different rules. Your media presence extends beyond what you do in print, video and social media. It's how you present to customers, staff, clients. Think holistically and strategically about the image you want to portray. Once your brand is established, be consistent in every way. It's good to surprise your audience now and again, to entertain a bit, to employ strategic content marketing tactics to engage them, for instance. But above all, people appreciate knowing what to expect - substance, style, all of the above.
